video.title: The centuries-old debt that's still paying interest
video.description:
In the archives of Yale University, there's a 367-year-old bond from the water authority of Lekdijk Bovendams, in the Netherlands. And it's still paying interest.

Prof. Geert Rouwenhorst for his time and explanation
All the team at the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

content.summary:
A 1648 Dutch bond is still paying interest today. A small water authority near the River Lek sold a perpetual bearer bond to fund levee repairs, and more than three and a half centuries later, Yale University owns it and still collects the annual payout. The punchline is modest but remarkable: about ‚Ç¨11.35 a year, still honored without an end date.

First, let‚Äôs demystify the ‚Äúperpetual‚Äù part. In early finance, many bonds had no maturity date; the idea that a bond must be paid back in full on a set date is actually a later innovation. Perpetual debt works a bit like stock‚Äîongoing payments without repaying the principal‚Äîexcept it lasts only as long as the issuer survives.

Now, why did this one survive? Dutch water boards were special-purpose governments created to manage levees and drainage, because rivers ignore city and provincial borders. They could levy taxes on everyone protected by the dikes, and unlike national governments, they didn‚Äôt go to war. That combination‚Äîsteady tax revenue and low existential risk‚Äîmade them unusually reliable payers, the municipal equivalent of a triple‚ÄëA credit profile.

Zooming in on the specifics, the issuer was the Water Board of Lekdijk Bovendams. Over time, it merged into a larger authority called Hoogheemraadschap De Stichtse Rijnlanden, which still services the debt. The original principal was 1,000 carolus guilders, which later converted through different Dutch currencies and, eventually, to euros. The interest rate was reduced at some point, leaving today‚Äôs annual payment at ‚Ç¨11.35.

Because it‚Äôs a bearer bond, whoever physically holds the document can claim the interest. Each payment was literally written on the bond itself, and when the parchment filled up, they attached an extra sheet to keep recording. When Yale bought the bond in 2003, the last payment on record was from 1976, so they collected 27 years of back interest at once. The bond stayed at Yale for a while, then in 2015 they caught up again on the missed years from 2004 through 2015.

There‚Äôs an amusing economic wrinkle. Flying someone to the Netherlands to present the bond costs far more than the interest itself. The water authority could probably stop paying with minimal legal risk, but for roughly a euro a month they preserve a centuries‚Äëlong promise and gain a steady stream of good publicity. That‚Äôs cheap heritage marketing, and it keeps a living thread of financial history intact.

So what‚Äôs the bottom line? A perpetual bond can endure for centuries when it‚Äôs backed by a stable, tax‚Äëfunded institution with minimal reasons to fail. Yale gets a token payout and a great story, and the Dutch water authority gets continuity and goodwill at a bargain price‚Äîproof that, sometimes, the value of a financial instrument is as much about trust and tradition as it is about cash flow.
